formats.name: micro_confession
formats.instruction: Share a brief, honest personal confession related to the topic. Use only one sentence. Evoke a strong emotion or unexpected twist. 15-30 words.

formats.name: reverse_question
formats.instruction: Pose a question that is actually answered by the topic itself, then provide a short but insightful answer. Limit to 40-70 words.

formats.name: found_object_story
formats.instruction: Describe a fictional ‘found object’ (like a diary entry, message in a bottle, or lost note) that reveals something surprising about the topic. Create the vibe of a real discovery. 80-150 words.

formats.name: paradox_unravel
formats.instruction: Present a paradox or contradiction relating to the topic, then attempt to unravel or explain it in detail. Use two concise paragraphs. 180-350 words.

formats.name: visual_walkthrough
formats.instruction: Imagine describing a physical scene or image that illustrates the topic. Use sensory details and spatial description. Aim for cinematic effect. 120-200 words.

formats.name: pattern_alert
formats.instruction: Spot a recurring pattern or motif connected to the topic across history, media, or culture. List three examples and discuss the significance of the pattern. 100-220 words.

formats.name: future_letter
formats.instruction: Write a letter from yourself in the future (five years ahead) about how the topic evolved. Be speculative, personal, and use a hopeful or cautionary tone. 165-320 words.

formats.name: contrarian_flash
formats.instruction: Deliver a hot take that sharply disagrees with the common wisdom on the topic. Use two sentences only. Make it bold, concise, and slightly provocative. 25-40 words.

formats.name: myth_remix
formats.instruction: Retell a classic myth or urban legend, but remix it in a modern or unexpected way that connects to the topic. Keep it short and punchy. 60-120 words.

title_styles: Frame the title as a question nobody ever asks about the topic.
Use a metaphor or unexpected analogy to name the topic, e.g. 'X is the Tinder of Y'.
Start the title with a dramatic dilemma, e.g. 'If X happens, does Y even matter?'
Reference a famous quote or meme, but substitute words related to the topic.
Use a single-word title followed by a mysterious ellipsis, e.g. 'Redacted...' or 'Uprising...'
structure_variants: Embed a micro-story (real or imagined) at the start, then unpack its meaning.
Alternate between fact and fantasy every paragraph.
Break content into contrasting opinions: one pro, one con, one wild card.
Nest your main argument inside a riddle or puzzle, then reveal the answer at the end.
Frame every section as a different time period: past, present, future.
